node.title: Verdict reached in federal civil rights trial over George Floyd's death
node.description: The jury heard four weeks of testimony in the civil rights trial of three former police officers involved in the death of George Floyd.
node.content: ["The jury has reached a verdict in the federal civil rights trial of three former police officers involved in the death of George Floyd. The verdict is expected to be announced in court shortly.\u00a0", "Former Minneapolis police officers Thomas Lane, Tou Thao and J. Alexander Kueng are accused of violating Floyd's civil rights during his arrest and death by denying him medical care. Kueng and Thao are also charged with failing to intervene to stop fellow officer Derek Chauvin, who had his knee on Floyd's neck.", "In closing arguments, the prosecution maintained that all three officers violated Floyd's rights and their duties by not immediately offering him first aid when he began to struggle to breathe.\u00a0", "The defense highlighted the officers' testimonies that they believed Floyd was still breathing, and placed some of the blame on a lack of police training. They cited training and precedent that led the officers to defer to Chauvin, who was their superior.\u00a0", "Chauvin was convicted of murder in state court in April, and pleaded guilty to a federal civil rights charge in December.\u00a0 U.S. District Judge Paul Magnuson emphasized to jurors in this trial that Chauvin's convictions should not influence their decision.\u00a0", "On May 25, 2020, the four officers responded to a call where 46-year-old Floyd had been accused of using a counterfeit $20 bill. After Floyd was handcuffed, Chauvin pinned him to the ground with his knee on Floyd's neck for over nine minutes.\u00a0", "Surrounding them were bystanders who were captured on video yelling at the officers that Floyd was unable to breathe.\u00a0", "This trial focused on the actions of Lane, Thao and Kueng. During the fatal stop, Kueng knelt on Floyd's back while Lane held his legs down.\u00a0", "All three men testified that they suggested alternative methods to restrain Floyd. Lane, the rookie White officer who first called the ambulance, said a decision was made to not use a hobble device, which allows the person to breathe easier while restrained, because it would require them to call a supervisor after he was detained.\u00a0", "He also said he suggested they roll Floyd on his side after he stopped resisting, but Chauvin said no. Towards the end of his testimony, Lane agreed the situation \"could have been handled differently.\"", "During his testimony, Thao, who is Hmong American, said he was in charge of crowd control and never checked Floyd's pulse. He also highlighted the three officers' lack of experience and rank compared to Chauvin.\u00a0", "When asked why he didn't tell Chauvin to get off of Floyd's neck, Thao responded, \"I think I would trust a 19-year veteran to figure it out,\" CBS Minnesota reported.\u00a0", "Kueng, the rookie Black officer who knelt on Floyd's leg, testified that probationary officers were taught to always defer to a superior to the point of unquestioning obedience. He added that he was concerned about their ability to keep Floyd contained, but followed Chauvin's lead.\u00a0", "\"He was my senior officer and I trusted his advice,\" Kueng said.", "Lane, Kueng and Thao will also face a state trial, scheduled for June, on charges of aiding and abetting murder and manslaughter."]
